Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Starting with the normative process description Let me break down the key steps and constraints mentioned 1 The process always starts with Receive order 2 After receiving the next step must be Check inventory 3 Depending on inventory availability If sufficient Then proceed to Authorize payment must be after Check inventory and before Package Then Package items after authorization before shipping Then Ship order after packaging Finally Close order must be the last step If insufficient inventory After Check inventory go directly to Cancel order Then Close order must be next and close is the final step 4 Constraints Authorize payment cant happen before Check inventory Package cant happen before authorization Ship cant happen after cancellation Close must be last in all cases Also the key is the sequence must follow the specific branches either the full path Receive Check Auth Package Ship Close or the short path Receive Check Cancel Close

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 1 Timeline R C Auth Package Ship Close This follows the full path correctly Check inventory first then auth then package ship close All steps in order No violations here So this is compliant

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 2 R C Package Auth Ship Close Hmm here after Check they went directly to Package without doing Auth first The norm says Auth must come after Check and before Package So this skips Auth between Check and Package Thats a violation The sequence here is R C Package which violates the requirement that Package cant come before Auth So this case is non-compliant

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 3 R C Auth Cancel Ship Close Wait after AUTH they did Cancel But according to the norm if inventory is sufficient you cant cancel The cancellation branch is only when inventory is insufficient But here the Check was done first so inventory was presumably sufficient but then they did Auth and then Cancel That seems odd

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Breaking it down After Auth which should be after Check and before Package they went to Cancel Thats not part of the intended flow Cancel is only for when inventory is insufficient so once youve checked and found sufficient you cant cancel So thats a violation Then after Cancel they tried to Ship But according to the norm if you cancel the next step should be Close So Ship after Cancel is definitely a violation Also Ship cant happen after a cancellation because the cancellation is supposed to end the process before moving to fulfillment steps So this case has multiple violations

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 4 R C Cancel Close This seems to follow the short path correctly After Check they went straight to Cancel and then Close Thats exactly the intended path for insufficient inventory So this is compliant No violations here

Name: Deductive Reasoning - NE
Text: Case 5 R C Auth Package Ship Close Same as Case 1 This is the full path correctly followed So compliant

Name: Backtracking - IND
Text: Now let me double-check each case again to make sure I didnt miss anything Case 3 again The key issue here is that after Check which should indicate sufficient inventory they proceeded to Auth which is okay but then Cancel Cancel is only supposed to happen when inventory is insufficient Since they checked and presumably had sufficient stock the Cancel here is a mistake So the process should not have Cancel in that path

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So summarizing the violations Case 2 Missing Authorize payment before Package items The sequence after Check is Package skipping Auth So the rule Authorize payment should only occur after Check and before Package is violated here Case 3 Multiple violations a After Check sufficient inventory they proceeded to Cancel which is only allowed when inventory is insufficient So the Cancel is in the wrong branch b After Cancel they attempted to Ship order which is not allowed in the cancellation path the next step after Cancel should be Close only So Ship after Cancel is a violation So Cases 2 and 3 are the ones violating the process
